Name: Avdheshshukla
Title: Phenomenal Waste of Tax Payers Money
Review: The Ambedkar Park is concrete park, decorated with stones & sculptures. It is quite beautiful & artistic but extremely hot & uncomfortable, particularly in noon. It was widely criticized for the amount of funds spent by the government on construction & subsequent reconstructions. The park is one of the most famous & well built parks in India and though there is some rush at the ticket counter, the vast size ensures enough space to crowd inside.The best time to visit is evening & rain, but remember to bring your umbrella/raincoat as the park offers little shelter.Overall a good place to go on weekdays.

Name: Liz M
Title: What a waste of the indian peoples money
Review: This monument in the centre of Lucknow is a concrete eyesore. At a cost in the multi millions the monument is hot, unattractive and offers little in the way of comfort or shelter for the locals or tourists. To give a little explanation there are 64 concrete elephants each one cost 1 million rupees. This monument was commission by 1 politician at the expense of the Indian people

Name: Amalendu Nath
Title: Must see park at Lucknow.
Review: Made by lots of white and red stones,marbles..Situated at the centre of the Lucknow city.Spread area , lots of green.

Name: amars777
Title: Must see place in Lucknow
Review: Located in Gomtinagar, central Lucknow. It is spread over 107 acres. It’s a great monument to remember the master who created the Indian Constitution. It is mesmerisingly neat and shining.

Name: Anwar S
Title: lots of elephant
Review: bhut he aacha park hai gomti nagar mai hai or elephant to bhut hai par natural nhe hai winter mai jaaye or enjoy kare is best for winter

Name: Anchal maurya
Title: Nice place ..I request to all people.who want to get peaceful place .I recommend them to visit temple.
Review: I am very glad to visit such unique temple ☺️. I like the art and creativity made on temple 🙏Lots of people come to take a look of God Shiv ji ..and get lots of blessings.

Name: Shan
Title: Sacred place 🙏🏻HAR HAR MAHADEV🙏🏻
Review: One of the most sacred place(temple) in lucknow with positive vibration and devotional ambience. Always love to visit and worship Lord🙏HAR HAR MAHADEV❤️

Name: Tanvi
Title: Felt positive vibes here
Review: Temple is one of the oldest temple of lord Shankar here in Lucknow . I felt positive and peaceful here .

Name: Somaseshu Gutala
Title: My Visit to Mankameshwar Temple, Lucknow
Review: In Lucknow most of the temples are small with simple construction without much sculptures and carvings. Most of them were re-constructed by Mahants with the co-operation of philanthropists and devotees. This temple though small has wonderful frescoes carved on friezes on four sides of the temple tower. We find the carvings of Durga, Kalabhairav and Hanuman emerging out of the mouth of the demoness Surasa. This temple is located between Hasanganj and Daliganj area in the heart of the city on the left bank of the Gomati River. This temple is managed by Mahant Devagya Puri (Arunima Singh), the first woman Mahant in Lucknow. According to legends King Lakshman came here after leaving Sita in exile and worshipped Lord Shiva to get mental peace. Later a temple with twent-three golden urns was built by King Navdhanu after conquering his enemy. In twelfth century this temple was destroyed and plundered by Yemeni invaders. Five hundred years ago Naga sadhus re-built this temple.

Name: Niraj K
Title: One of the most believed Temple of Lord Shiva in Lucknow.
Review: On Monday through out the day it is crowded by devotees with long ques. It is the first Temple in Lucknow who started manufacturing Organic Manure by disposing the flowers as offering.

Name: Pushpendra M
Title: PEACEFUL PLACE
Review: The one of the best place in lucknow. Its really gives so mentally freshness and relaxation. Totally peaceful place.

Name: riya g
Title: Jsi mankameshwar mahadev
Review: My bestest place in Lucknow ❤️😇jai Bholenaath..m Bholenaath ki bahut badi bhakt hu..main vha bachpan se aa rhi hu.. fall in love eid this place..my heart ❤️

Name: SAURAV C
Title: Place for Gods Blessings
Review: Place is the ideal place for solace and always good to feel blessed once you are there. All the reason to be blessed by the Divine powers.

Name: Bobby J
Title: Hindu temple of Lord shiva.
Review: The mandir is a revered Hindu temple enshrined by Lord Shiva. The temple was the first to have a woman priest. Mondays are considered the most auspicious; hence the busiest days of the week in the temple.

Name: kamal_innovaa
Title: Lord Shiv Temple
Review: It is very famous Shiv Temple.During Saw an yesterday was first Monday ,day for Lord Shiv.there was very long and huge crowd for Fatshan of Lord Shiva.We were blessed to be there

Name: KhannaK491
Title: Must visit temple of Lucknow
Review: I am a frequent visitor of the temple. It is most crowded on Mondays (considered special day for Shiv puja)The temple is located near Lucknow university and has another famous temple - Hanuman Setu across the road from it.You have to stand on long queues to visit the shrine on mondays, during Saawan and people queue since midnight and wee hours of the morning to get in.Its reminds me of Kedarnath in the way it is built. Do visit if you're a shiv devotee!! If not, go for the peace and tranquility it offers.

Name: himanshulko
Title: Peace of Mind
Review: Its is one of oldest temple in lucknow. it is adjacent to lucknow  univeristy. The Idol of Lord Shiva was amazing. The ambiance was great & peaceful place. .

Name: PD1059
Title: Aarti time is great time to be in temple.
Review: Mahant is lady full of energy, soft-spoken and has tried to clean temple premises and nearby areas though still, a lot needs to be done.

Name: Rasheedur Rahman Shihab
Title: Religious Place
Review: One of the most popular temples in Lucknow is the Mankameshwar Temple in the Daliganj locality of Lucknow.

Name: Sandeep V
Title: Bom Bom bhole
Review: Mankameshwar LucknowThis antique Temple is situated near Saraswati Ghat, on the banks of the river Yamuna. This old temple is exactly located in between Hasanganj and Daliganj area.Temple timings: All days of the week; 5:00 am – 12:00 pm, 4:00 pm – 9:00 pmVisit duration: 30 minutes-60 minutes; No Entry feeAddress of Mankameshwar Temple LucknowMankameshwar Mandir Marg, MukarimnagarHasanganj, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh – 226001Phone no.: (0522)2307037Nearest landmark is Lal Bahadur Shashtri Boy’s hostel. This divine place can be reached by hiring a cab or an auto rickshaw from Railway station and Airport.

Name: sun_abhay
Title: OLD LORD SHIV TEMPLE
Review: Oldest lord Shiv temple with huge devotee, a very peaceful place for worship, having strong faith of Hindu community of Lucknow and nearby towns ,

Name: Mayank Srivastava
Title: Holy place
Review: This is a very holy place. Mankameshwar temple is considered most holy Shiva Temple of Lucknow & attracts large crowd on Mondays and in holy month of Shravan.

Name: Footprints727663
Title: Ancient Temple
Review: I went to Mankameshwar Temple. Mankameshwar Temple is one of four ancient temples dedicated to Lord Shiva located on the four corners of Agra City. The history of Mankameshwar Mandir takes us to the Dwapara Era, when Lord Shri Krishna was born in Mathura. It is great place to go.

Name: Babu Yelamanchili
Title: Remotely Located inside the streets
Review: This is a well known ancient temple famous for the disciples believing in fulfillment of wishes seeking blessings from LORD SHIVA .

Name: Rohit T
Title: A shiva temple
Review: This temple is auspicious for many devotees. One of the famous religious points of the city. Basically a Shiva temple, other deities are also found here. Devotees turnout is maximum during Shivratri and the month of Saavan

Name: Aman K
Title: Great
Review: Very special temple of Lord Shiva. Mankameshwar mandir is small and beautiful, there is a lot of crowd here. Once sure comes.

Name: kamal_innovaa
Title: Take darshan of Bhole Baba Lord Shiva
Review: We were there on Monday morning to worship Shankar Bhagwan as well Parvati Maiya.There was huge crowd being on Monday.Really requested to fulfill wishes as ask for.Lot of flawers and milk was given on Shivling.Great to feel darshan in the morning.

Name: Vibhu S
Title: Mankameshwar Mandir
Review: This holy place of Hinduism and very famous Mandir of Shiv shankar ji and built up look like a guffa in Lucknow

Name: JITENDRA Singh
Title: beautiful
Review: this is the on of the oldest temple in lucknow very worshiper come here for pray and worship ..must see

Name: skk1509
Title: #blessed
Review: Shri "Mankameshwar" Mandir is an ancient & the most popular temple of Lord Shiva on the banks of River Gomti in Lucknow. It sees many devotees everyday, throughout the year. Be #blessed.

Name: vinitasaraf2015
Title: Om Namah Shivay
Review: Its a very pios temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Very popular with the locals many bells are at the entrance

Name: Gurumurthy Bhargava
Title: Visit for seeking the well being of all.
Review: Mankameshwar Temple is believed to be a very old Hindu temple of Lord Shiva located near the banks of River Gomti.As per the Hindu traditions offering milk here on the Shivalinga particularly  on every Monday brings peace, prosperity and fulfills all the wishes of its  worshipper, as the name of the temple suggests.One can buy milk packet and flowers for the  offering  from the nearby vendors and can also leave one's footwear with them, as one has to enter the Holy temple barefoot. Along with my wife could offer Milk to the Holy Shivalinga peacefully and felt blessed.Photography is allowed in the complex but not inside the Holy sanctum.A must pilgrimage for all Hindus .International tourists may find it interesting if they want to feel the pulse of India.

Name: Dryogendranath M
Title: Visit to Mankameshwar Madir
Review: This is an old temple of Lord Shiva and as the name suggests, people believe that their wishes can be accomplished by performing Pujan/Darshan of Lord Shiva. This is auspicious place during the month of Shrawan.

Name: Ujjwal S
Title: Depends
Review: If u are a family.. visiting lko for a long span of time.. and want to give a religious touch to the tour... u can visit the temple..If u are visiting for a day or two.. u can skip it..  its simple temple.. nothing special about it.. Although it is old and famous temple in lko.

Name: P N M
Title: Siddhapeeth Temple
Review: Mankameshwar Temple is the Siddhapeeth Mandir of Lord SHIV.If you pray for your demands , It will be completed. Thousands of people visit this mandir in Saavan month

Name: SMRITY S
Title: Good old hindu temple
Review: We used to visit it several times in childhood when it was not so densly crowded. But still the place is sacred till date & nice exp every time you go there

Name: journey2016
Title: JAI BHOLE NATH TEMPLE
Review: mankameshwar temple is really really famous in lucknow. this is the better place to make worship of bholenath. this temple is in back side of lucknow university. near daliganj. some times i use to come here for peace and to ask for something from bholenath. in monday and mahasivratri occassion there is lots of crowd here.if you have any problem come here for peace, definitly your problem will be decrease.

Name: Sundeepgupta
Title: beautiful.
Review: This temple has a grand door and is famous among local people. people usually come here in mass on tuesdays so its crowdy that time.

Name: chetan1586
Title: Ancient Shiv Temple
Review: Mankameshwar temple is an ancient shiv temple in Lucknow. The access to the temple is through a narrow road.

Name: Aman A
Title: Om Namah Shivaya
Review: This Lord Shiva temple is located at a distance of just 3 kms from Hazratganj chowk. The place is blissful, spiritual and full of positive energy.It is also said that anyone who wishes anything in this temple shall come true.

Name: Rahul Saini
Title: "Jai Shiv Omkaraay!!!!"
Review: Good to go for devotee of Lord SHIVA........situated in narrow road...but architecture is awesome....bells ringing and devotional songs make to spend some more time.

Name: JAGDISH RAVAL
Title: Temple of Lord Shiva
Review: Believed to be almost ancient, Mankameshwar Mandir is a popular temple of LORD SHIVA in Lucknow. This temple is dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva and it sees many devotees everyday, throughout the year, specially on Mondays, which is considered to be an auspicious day to worship the lord shiva.visit once when you are in Lucknow.

Name: satyaprakash375
Title: Mankameshwar Mandir
Review: mankameshwar mandir is very old temple of lord Shiva, I have visited this many times... and its an awesome temple...

Name: wish2traveltheworld
Title: A Hindu Temple
Review: Well this is not very different from other hindu temple in the (as i have been to many) country instead that it seems a bit older. It is dedicated to Yogi Shiva and people chant mantras and do spiritual practices here. For me it is  not a must in lucknow.

Name: Taz_Bh
Title: Your regular temple.
Review: Mankameshwar means "That who grants what your inner conscious seeks". It is said to be a very old temple. Though it is located in a narrow lane in what seemed to be a residential area. Has a huge 'Shivaling'. I actually had to tell off the priest who's phone kept ringing while I tried to recite the Shiva Tandava Strot.No special architecture that we saw. As per me it would be your regular temple... But then...I'm a Hindu...so we go to temples all the time...

Title: A unique Shiva temple
Review: The Shiva temple is very old and famous, a must visit to fulfil your wishes, people come from all part of our country, on Monday there will be huge rush especially in the evening time so if possible please avoid your visit on Monday, parking of car is difficult in  front of the temple so park your vehicle from a distance and then walk  to the gate of the temple.Senior citizens should take proper precaution due to the rush,If you are coming to Lucknow then you  must pay a visit.

Name: SUROJIT G
Title: Quaint temple
Review: A must visit during your trip to Lucknow. You would feel the inner peace after having a darshan of Shambunath jee

Name: ApurbaRoy
Title: Temple
Review: A temple of Hindu to worship, a place of deity with much faith in devotees. One can have pious feeling here and find peace from hectic day to day life.

Name: DotDivx
Title: Shiv Temple
Review: I have visited this many times... and its an awesome temple.... Visit this early morning (say 5 - 6 AM) on a Monday.

Name: abhineetsingh
Title: Mankameshwar temple
Review: Har Har mahadev....Mankameshwar temple lies in the banks of river Yamuna, near Saraswathi Ghat. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva. Mondays in the Sawan month  is considered auspicious and devotees pay visit to the temple during this time.

Name: Pawan_Shrotria
Title: Very Famous Temple
Review: A very famous Shiv Ji Temple. Devotees come from all areas of Lucknow.Amazing crowd on the festival 'MahaShivRatri'.A must to there on this day.

Name: rajeshwar singh
Title: beautiful temple of lord shiva
Review: our family visited temple in 1st,jan,2014 it is beautiful temple of lord shiva if you are staying in lucknow try to visit this place very positive vibe one can feel after you reach temple premises.too crowded so try to go there early morning .....have a good time..Regardsrajeshwar singh

Name: ar_faraz
Title: Oldest Shiva Temple
Review: its a centre of faith, very old temple of Shiva, located in the narrow lanes of Daliganj. specially on Shivratri thousand of thousand people make que to get a glimpse of Lord Shiva.

Name: harry2020
Title: Relaxing
Review: The atmosphere is very relaxing to the mind if you are not there on Mondays or some special days like Shivratris. Its too crowded in those days. Maybe you'll have to wait in a queue for 4-5 hrs.

Name: umesh_12
Title: Mankamana
Review: those who are athiest...having faith in God...should visit once.....very famous temple......man ko badi shanti milegi....thoda samaya dain aur wahan baithe....

Name: swarnaprabha k
Title: temple  is  pretty  old  , Manakameswar   grant  wishes
Review: I  was  told  the  temple  is  pretty  old , but the  temple  was observed to be  well  maintained  and  did  not  appear  to  be  that  old  .  That prompted me to conclude that it  was  an  old  temple  renovated from time to time and maintained beautifully. This  temple  is  dedicated  for  worshipping  lord  Siva . The temple is very much  inside  the  city  of  luck now,  in  Hasanganj  area  .The  lord  Manakameswar   grant  wishes .  One  can  also  visit  the Ramakrishna  matha  which is pretty nearby, which is worth a visit.

Name: Akshay Sharma
Title: A reduced image of Bara Imambara
Review: This is located next to Bara imambara but the similarities end with the name only. From the outside the structure is good but Bara Imambara is worth the visit.

Name: Rohit B
Title: Picture perfect!
Review: Much smaller in comparison to the Bara Imambara and less visited by tourists, this destination is probably just a picture spot, with very little to see around. The only interesting place inside to see is probably the Hammam spa.

Name: flyingwish
Title: Must Include with Bara Imambara
Review: Most visitors skip the chotta imambara. They should not. I found it to be equally impressive as its big brother and it is located less than a Km away. A simple and cheap rickshaw ride can be done between the two monuments.

Name: silva s
Title: Hidden gem
Review: We do not know why everyone discouraged us to visit this place.  we visited in afternoon and it was a nice experience. it is like a hidden gem. the intricate work on the imambara is a treat for eye for heritage lovers. it also has exquisite collection of candelabra.

Name: gpradeepshenoy
Title: Small good place to visit in Lucknow
Review: A walk of 15 -20 minutes from bara Imambara through roomi darwaza is required to reach chota Imambara. Or there are auto's/tongas available in front of bara Imambara which can be hired to reach chota Imambara.Entrance ticket for chota Imambara can be taken at bara Imambara (Rs 50 combined ticket for visiting bara Imambara, bowli,bhul bhulaya & picture gallery) or taken at chota Imambara (I think rs 20 is the cost of entrance ticket to chota Imambara if taken at chota Imambara).      Guide charges are fixed and displayed at entrance. I did not take guide here.       Chota Imambara complex has a hamam and mausoleum too.          One cannot enter inside the mausoleums here .  Footwear has to removed only when we want to enter Chota Imambara. Chota Imambara is beautiful. On the day I went photography even with mobile phone was not allowed inside chota Imambara because of Muharram.         A beautiful place not be be missed while in Lucknow.

Name: JoyBose
Title: Beautiful architecture and a holy place as well as tourist place
Review: This imambara was built in early 1800s by the nephew of the Nawab who built the bada imambara. Entry is Rs 20 for Indians and hiring a guide costs Rs 200. It is worth hiring a guide to understand the intricacies of this building and its history and significance. This complex comprises the main building, the Taj mahal replica tomb of the nawab's daughter, the shahi hamam for baths and the "jawab" of identical building to the daughter's tomb. The main building has the shrines of the emperor and his mother. The main tomb is a holy building, of Shia muslim holy significance. It is of more significance during the muharram procession, when people of all religions can get the holy blessing. One must take off the shoes before entering the main imambara tomb. It costs Rs 2 per shoe to keep them. The shahi hamam is where the nawab used to bath, it had arrangements for both hot and cold bath, in Persian style of hamam. There is also near the entrance a fish structure denoting the emblem of the Lucknow nawabs. The architecture of the main buildings and white tomb and its jabab are most beautiful.

Name: Syedabid2014
Title: Amazingly beautiful
Review: Could not visit Chhota Imambara on my last visit so this time we did and boy.. It is a piece of history. Bewitchingly beautiful and stunning...

Name: MPJ
Title: Lucknow visit
Review: Beautiful place and well maintained. Worth a visit any day. Religious sanctity of the place has to be respected and adhered to. Islamic architecture at one of its best.

Name: GRVARCH
Title: A good place.
Review: This is a religious place of Shia Muslims.Its premises is attractive and clean.A mosque and Shahi hamam is also here.There are many tazias and historical things are here to see.

Name: Soumyajit Saha
Title: Chhota Imambara
Review: Chhota Imambara is a historical place and one should visit this place once. It can be reached by public buses.

Name: pilgrim_gsa
Title: Historical
Review: The one ticket that holds good for other places in the area can be used also for visiting this place .One can visit and admire it's historical roots .

Name: Anuradha
Title: Marvellous
Review: Don’t go by the name chhota Imambara, it’s very big compound and Imambara has a beautiful architecture and style. A must visit place if you are in Lucknow.

Name: Harsh V
Title: one time visit
Review: the place is good for tourists who come from outside the place has a front beautiful flower garden but as compare to bad bada imambara the place is not so interesting

Name: niya27
Title: Walking distance from Bada Imambad
Review: Chota imambada isn't far away from Bada imambada. If you're fit, then better to walk there. There are many other attractions in between such as clock Tower, art gallery, rumi darwaza etc.

Name: Tanvi
Title: Worth visiting
Review: I visited here after visiting bada Imambara . It is as beautiful as Bara Imambara . Felt good here . It is neat and clean worth visiting . Architecture is also beautiful .

Name: Saumyendra
Title: Chhota Imambara Visit
Review: Beautiful! Shall remember always- the monument, the chandeliers, the Taazia, the history behind it all....

Name: Somaseshu Gutala
Title: My Visit to Chota Imambara ( Imambara Hussainabad Mubarak), Lucknow
Review: Just two kms away from Bada Imambara on the west side, Chota Imambara is seen which is admired for its artistic beauty as Palace of Lights. It is located on Husanabad Road in Daulatganj in Lucknow. This was built by Mohd.Ali Shah, the Nawab of Awadh in 1838 as a congregation hall for Shia Muslims to celebrate Muharram and other festivals. Azim-ullah-Khan, Superintendent of ordnance and Buildings, supervised the construction of this gold-plated building with many large and smaller domes with ribbed design. The Nawab in order to provide employment to workers during the severe drought period undertook the construction of this monument. The significance of the holy five is symbolized here by five main doorways. There are two halls and a platform (Shehnasheen) on which the Zarih(the replica of the protective grill that is kept over the grave of Imam Hussain at Karbala, Iraq) is seen. The main hall or Azhakhana is a large green and white bordered hall with a gilded dome decorated with chandeliers imported from Belgium, golden edged mirrors and crystal glass lamp stands. On the south of the main hall is the main platform with arches where the banners and flags of the small army of Imam Hussain are seen. A number of Tazias made of silver, ivory and sandalwood are kept on the main platform or Shahnasheen. There is also a big Tazia that is made of wax and tinsel paper kept in the main hall. The tombs of Nawab Mohd. Alishah and his mother are seen in the central hall. Their bodies are buried below the floor in the basement of the central hall. In the central hall the royal throne, the red crown of the king and the silver Mimbar or pulpit on which the orator is seated when he addresses audience are also seen. On the walls and pillars of the hall, Quran verses are written in Islamic calligraphy in the shape of a tiger, a horse and a bird, fixed in wooden frames. An antique Persian clock and a glass fish tank from Japan are other curious objects found in this spacious hall. The way to this Imambara is embellished with a flowing stream flowing through the center of the garden. Water for fountains and other water bodies is channelized from Gomti River. This building constructed in Indo-Islamic and Persian style has a Charbagh pattern—a single stream running through the center of the garden. There are two triple-arched gateways on the east and west as entrances. In between them is the main gate with a heavy door. . The three-storied main entrance gate is seen with a bronze fish fixed at the top of the arched gateway. This bronze fish works as a weather vane one finds the sacred five emblems mounted atop the main gate to signify the holy five members of Prophet Mohammad’s family. Opposite the main gate is Naubat Khana where large drums were beaten to announce the hours of the day. Two metal Grecian figures in bronze connected to spikes on the top of the gate act as lightning conductors. On the left side of the main building is seen a mosque with two minarets , a replica of Taj Mahal, where the tombs of Nawab’s daughter, Zinat Asiya, his son and her husband along with the tomb of Nawab’s consort are found. Non-Muslims are not allowed inside the mosque. On the other side a similar structure facing the mausoleum was built to maintain architectural symmetry and balance. This building was used as treasury. Outside the Imambara is a watchtower called Satkhanda or tower of seven stories. But only four stories were seen as the king passed away and the construction work was stopped. This tower was built between 1837 and 1842. On the model of Qutub Minar and the tower of Pisa this tower was constructed in Indo-Islamic style and was meant for lunar observation.Mohd.Ali Shah and his queen Malka Afaq Jahan deposited 26 lakhs with East India Company to form Hussianabad Endowment Trust to look after the religious buildings they had built and for observance of Muharrum and other connected functions. To the left of the main gate, Shahi Imam (Royal bath) with a complicated system of drainage is seen which supplies hot water to the gigantic bath tub. This building has been renovated in later times. Tickets purchased at Bada Imambara gives one access to Chota Imambara and Picture Gallery. Alexis Soltykoff, the Russian prince, who visited this place in 1841, described this monument as the “Kremlin of India.”Really as someone said, this monument is “ small in name, but big in wonder.” There are many worth seeing monuments nearby such as Jama Masjid, Clock Tower and Rumi Dawaja. The opening hours of this Imambara are from 8.00 a.m. to 6.30 p.m.

Name: ShikshaC
Title: Beautiful Architecture…
Review: Chota Imambra is a religious place and thus women are required to cover their heads inside. You get scarfs at the entry in case you do not have something to cover your head. The complex has a worship area, replicas of Taj Mahal and a shahi imam (royal bath) within the complex. You can take a guide who will give you details about the outer complex. There is another guide inside the worship area.

Name: RAMESHSHIRALI
Title: WORTH WHILE VISIT
Review: After a extensive tour of Bara Imambara the Chota Imambara is not to be missed. It will take less than 30 minute to go around.Its neat and clean and interesting site.

Name: Let's Go Sightseeing
Title: Imambara Hussainabad Mubarak
Review: It's called the Chota Imambara popularly. But, its actual name is Imambara Hussainabad Mubarak. The first thing you'll notice is the goldfish at the entrance. It's actually an anemometer. One of the earliest ones in India I guess.Also, the golden statue at the entrance holds a chain that is connected to a spire. This works as earthing. You can visit the Shahi Hamam (royal bath) where you can see stained glass windows, an elaborate hot water system & a jacuzzi kind of setup.The Tomb of Princess Zinat Asiya is supposed to be a replica of the Taj Mahal. We, however, didn't see the likeness. Photography inside the Imambara hall is prohibited. But, the inside is worth seeing - chandeliers & crystal glass lamp-stands!P.S. Women are required to cover their heads here.

Name: FeatureSM
Title: Amazing place to visit .
Review: Hey guys this is amazing place to visit.U can see the historical structure and knowledgeable things.

Name: SunnyandBuster
Title: Smaller but more interesting
Review: I found the Chhota Imambara more interesting than the Bara Imambara. It was built by Muhammad Ali Shah in 1837 as his own mausoleum. As you enter the grounds there is a long reflecting pool and small replicas of the Taj Mahal on either side. Inside the structure you’ll find an astounding array of chandeliers from all over the world. There are framed portions of ancient scripture, items from Mecca, photos, accoutrements and more. The variety of items and artifacts is more extensive than at the Bara Imambara.

Name: Sparkling soul
Title: Visit
Review: Beautiful architecture. Although there's no official board declaring it as a no photo zone, you can't take photos inside the monument. You also have to maintain silence. Lots of chandeliers of different shape and style. Crowded on weekends, guide available to explain stuff. Must visit in Lucknow

Name: Abdulhameed A
Title: Small but nice
Review: The building dates back to around 1840. It contains an old bathtub for the king. It contains a collection of old Muslim Shia related items like shrine and old Quran.

Name: durham05
Title: Nice collection of chandeliers
Review: There is not a lot to see her. The gardens and nice and the exterior impressive. Inside one big room to see that features a large number of chandeliers and a couple of graves. Worth a look but won't take long.

Name: 982pradipb
Title: A Hurried Trip
Review: It is a beautiful monument , a little away from the Bara Imambara. It has a waterbody and garden in front . The chandeliers hung in the building are exquisite. It houses other rare artefacts also. Though smaller in size it is more beautiful than the bigger one

Name: Pushpendra M
Title: HISTORICAL
Review: One of the famous historical place in lucknow. Its like NAWAB MAHAL. It has great ARCHITECTURE value.

Name: Debjani Gupta
Title: CHOTA IMAMBARA LUCKNOW
Review: The old city of Lucknow and it’s heritage charm.If the weather is good it is quite enjoyable to take a walk down, from the Bara Imambara to the Chota Imambara and in between stop and marvel at the beautiful Rumi Darwaza and the majestic Husainabad Clock Tower. Numerous auto rickshaws are there to ferry one around if one chooses to.Enter through the gates and the dazzling Chota Imambara sits like a jewel amidst well maintained manicured gardens.Guides are available at the gates and for a token fee they make the tour inside rather interesting.Recounting stories attached with the various monuments inside as well as their significance.Starting with the Shahi Hamam on the left and its historical significance we are told that fresh water from the Gomti river gets piped here. Make your way past the Tank with the clear waters in the middle. On the right stands a mosque,a treasury building and a replica of the TajMahal (a mausoleum of the princess, daughter of the then Nawab of Avadh)At the end of the garden stands the Chota Imambara in all its beauty, an architectural marvel. Serene and tranquil.Beautiful arches with Arabic Calligraphy, sparkling chandeliers , and beautiful Tazias well preserved inside.A gentle old man inside, recounted the historical and religious significance of the various objects preserved inside.A must visit place, the Hussainabad Imambara, in the old city of the Nawabs.

Name: notacanada
Title: Serenity
Review: The mosque is small compared with Bara Imambara but its atmosphere of serenity and holiness makes up what it lacks in size. The imam was welcoming. Close to the entrance the Chhota Imambara’s hammam, a tranquil space with lovely blue-coloured walls, elegant tiles and stained glass windows could easily be overlooked, and almost disappears in the greenery surrounding it.

Name: Dr M Talha
Title: Nawabs of Lucknow
Review: It has great architectural value. One of the most beautiful buildings of Lucknow.  Moharram is celebrated here every year in which people from different countries participate. Must see.

Name: PaulJanet
Title: Small but charming
Review: Smaller than the Bara Imambara but beautifully constructed with attractive water feature and fine calligraphy

Name: Harsh V
Title: beauty place
Review: when my first visit to chhot emambara is not so good there is nothing to seeing or intersting think now a days there is some constraction work is going in the back of building just the one time visit place

Name: BlrTravR
Title: Architecture
Review: One of the popular sights of old city Lucknow, can take a cycle rickshaws from bada imambara to here.

Name: Daniel T
Title: Worth a visit
Review: Nicely maintained historical site. The lane leading to this place gets very crowded during local festival days, so plan your visit accordingly.Architecture is worth appreciating. Can visit with kids, not recommended on a hot weather day.

Name: Dan R
Title: Causal
Review: As there is no emergency exit, in case of any uncertainty it’s Very dangerous place to visit bulbuliya.

Name: Niraj K
Title: Mughal Architecture
Review: Chota Immanbara is just few meters away from Bara Imambara in old Lucknow. It is an excellent piece to study Mughal Architecture designing. Otherwise also it is a place which no tourist should miss to see if he is visiting Lucknow.

Name: Krupabn
Title: Beautiful but disorganized
Review: Chota Imambara is beautiful from outside and has beautiful buildings in premises but once you enter you feel it's so disorganized with so many chandeliers placed with no specific theme. Architecture is amazing

Name: keith h
Title: Fairytale Like.
Review: I was more entranced by The Chota Imambara than The Bara Imambara. The two are not so far apart, easily walkable & one passes through The Rumi Dawarza en route.    I read that expert's think that recent restoration has spoilt the original plasterwork. On this point I have no knowledge but I can say that I was entranced by the place. The Imambara is fronted by a long pool in which it's reflection is cast. A stunning mass of flowers to your left are simply glorious.  The outside of The Imambara was just in the final stages of being repainted in dazzling white with a covering of Quranic calligraphy picked out in black. The interior is richly decorated with Belgian glass chandelier's & tazia's.  A pair of white painted mosque's flank the pool.    The whole spctacle is entrancing. My 500r ticket obtained at The Bara Imambara covered the entrance fee here.

Name: Piyush50
Title: Chota Imambara
Review: The Chota Imambara is supposed to be a small imambara, the large one being Bara Imambara.It is an interesting place where the Sultan lived with all the methods of plumbing and hot water baths etc.The local guides are a pain if you don't want to get into very small detail, and they need to be warned as such.

Name: Rosalynde J
Title: Chandeliers to die for!
Review: This is an active religious building and ladies are expected to cover their heads so take a shawl. If you like chandeliers there are some fine examples in here. The architecture is stunning and the place is beautifully looked after too. Well worth a visit.

Name: srg45
Title: Very Good architecture!
Review: Just had a quick glimpse of this structure. Very beautiful and worth a visit ! It is close to the Bara Imambara so one can do it together . Made in white marble it is very different but good.

Name: nikrang
Title: Let down
Review: After seeing the Bara Imambara this seems a bit of a let down and we saw the place any way. The old Hamam was interesting and quite novel

Name: Ajeet N
Title: Petit, but beautiful
Review: This is much better preserved than its larger namesake. The courtyard has waterworks with a bridge. There are tajmahalesque structures on either side. The earthing for the main gate on either side is through beautiful metallic golden ladies. The main building has Islamic calligraphy on its walls.

Name: Arjun S
Title: Pretty, but limited attractions
Review: Drawing fewer crowds than the Bara Imambara, this monument has a beautiful facade.  The interiors have a number of chandeliers hanging that give the place an old world feel.

Name: Anuradha Manjul
Title: Explore Lucknow – Chota (small) Imambada or Hussainabad Imamabara
Review: When a tourist, a history lover thinks of various destinations in India, does the name Lucknow ring a bell? One may have heard of Lucknow, the capital of Uttar Pradesh for various political reasons, but Lucknow as a tourist destination or secret haven for history lovers is a rarity. A city which played an important role in India’s first war of independence; the revolt of 1857 (for freeing India from the clutches of Colonial Rule), a city which has traditionally been known for its rich cultural heritage, a city which was known for its Adab (good manners) and Tehzeeb (good breeding, politeness). Capital of erstwhile Awadh or Oudh, Lucknow sure deserves a bigger chunk in the tourist map of India and more space in the heart of history lovers.It is unfortunate that the Tourism department and the government is not keen on focussing in this area. The city has everything which can make it an ideal tourist spot – good connectivity with all the major cities in India and the world (due to the presence Chaudhary Charan Singh International Airport), hotels for all ranges - from luxury to budget, you name it and the city has it, major international hotel chains like Taj group, Marriottt, Radisson, Hilton etc. are present here, ample transportation options in the city, excellent shopping opportunity, food joints dishing out some mouth-watering local cuisine and yes a rich cultural and historical heritage. What else you can ask for?In this series we would talk about some the interesting, must visit destinations in Lucknow. Have just half a day to spend in Lucknow, don’t miss out on Bada Imambada, Chota Imambada, La Martiniere boys and the British Residency. We would start our exploring with Chota Imambada or Hussainabad Imamabara. Imambada is a building used by Shia Muslims, the practitioners of Shia Islam (2nd largest branch of Islam) for the purpose of Azadari – azadari, the practices/rituals related to mourning and lamentation commemorating the martyrdom of Imam Hussain (Husayn ibn Ali) grandson of Prophet Mohammed in the battle of Karbala, which takes place in the period of Muharram. Nawab was a title given by the Mughal emperors to semi-autonomous Muslim rules of princely states. The Nawabs of Awadh (Oudh) were Shia Muslims and belonged to a dynasty of Persian origin from Nishapur, Iran. Saadat Khan, Burhan-ul-Mulk (Mohammad Amin) was a Persian nobleman who was appointed the governor of Awadh (Oudh) in 1722 AD. His court was in Faizabad near Lucknow. The weakening of Mugal Empire in Delhi gave him an advantage in carving out the state of Awadh (around 1724 AD) with its capital both at Faizabad and Lucknow.Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah (1837-1842) built the Hussainabad Imamabara (1838), which is popularly known as Chota (small) Imambada. It is located in the Heritage Zone of Lucknow; after the Bada (big) Imambada (Asafi Imambada), cross the majestic Rumi Darwaaza (gate), on the same road after almost ½ a kilometre on the left. There are many Imambadas in Lucknow, each Imambada in Lucknow has different architectural style. This holds true for Hussainabad Imambada also. True to its name Chota Imambada is not large in size. After Satkhanda, there is a 3 storeyed gate (made of brick, painted in white), the boundary of the Imambada start just after that, but not recognisable now as there are many commercial establishments. There is a sign installed by the Tourism department which announces that one has arrived at Chota Imambada – there is a small grilled enclosure which leads to a non-descript looking entrance. There is an entry charge for this monument. One can either use the combined entry ticket (purchased at Bada Imambada) or pay an entry charge for Rs. 20.00. The females need to cover their heads while inside this monument. Head scarves are available on rent at the entry.On entering through this gate (which is 3 storeyed) the first thing which is visible is a small arched gateway (not in use), on top of which is a bronze fish (with open fins- making it look like a flying fish). This is an anemometer (a scientific instrument used for measuring wind speed). The use of fish figure could be because the emblem of Nawabs of Awadh (Oudh) was two fishes (mahi muratib – the order of the fish). The second unique thing which one can see are two life size female figurines (European influence is clearly visible here) on either sides holding chains which are connected to spikes at the top of the gate one had entered. This is another scientific device – this is a lightening conductor device and the female figurines are serving as earthing equipment.The non-descript gateway through which one had entered, from this side is an architectural marvel, 3 storeyed; painted in white, an example of a mix of Islamic and European architectural style. The top most level reminded me of many Gothic churches I have seen. Once inside one can see the beauty of the gateway. Decorated with Islamic calligraphy and symbols in black this is just not a gateway – it’s the Naubat Khana.The Chota Imambada has many different structures in the complex. There is a small waterbody in the complex which starts right after the gateway with Fish shaped anemometer and ends just before the platform of Azakhana (the main congregation hall). This water body in a way divides the complex into right part and left part. There are small iron bridges to cross over (now not in use).A structural balance has been created on both sides. The first building on the right is a small mosque, again painted in white. It is built on a high platform, again decorated with Islamic Calligraphy and symbols.One look at the next building and one can easily realise the love or impact Taj Mahal had on the Nawab and the architects. It’s an attempted miniature replica of Taj Mahal again painted in white (no this building is not made in marble, but of Lakhori bricks, plastered and painted in white). There are 4 graves in this building – that of Princess Zinat Asiya, daughter of Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah or as many would call him the 3rd king of Oudh (Awadh), Nawab’s son, son-in-law and one lady from royal family.Just opposite to this building on right there is a building on left which is popularly known as ‘Jawaab’ or answer or reply. It’s an attempted mirror image of the building on the right – thus in a way reply to the building on the right. This building served as the Treasury.Then one can see the Duldul Khana (stable for Duldul). Duldul is a spotless white (it has been referred as glowing by many writers – but we didn’t see that glow) horse which is a living replica of Zuljanah – the faithful mount of Imam Hussain Ali (grandson of prophet Mohammad). This is linked to the martyrdom of Imam Hussain in the battlefield of Karbala, the main theme of mourning rituals of Moharram. The horse in Lucknow remains mainly in isolation and is brought out in public during Moharram celebrations. This horse in Lucknow unlike other areas is especially raised for this purpose, its upkeep is paid by Hussianabad & Allied Trust (HAT) which was set up in 1838 by the Nawab himself. The horse has and would never be mounted. (P.S. – the horse is replaced on its death, there is no progeny).The next structure which lies right next to Azakhana is the kitchen area, we could see logs and logs of wood. The inside looks like a simple old style kitchen area with good drainage area.The Azakhana or the main congregation hall is the most beautiful building. It’s located on a raised platform and one has to climb stairs to reach the courtyard. Entry with shoes is not allowed – there are shoe stands on the left side and one has to pay a fee of Rs. 2.00 (current rate) for the services. The single level structure has gold plated dome. The exterior of this building is beautifully decorated in Islamic Calligraphy which is painted exquisitely in white on a black background. This is one of the most unique feature of this building. The Azakhana is divided into two halls and a Shehnasheen (a platform where Zarih, a replica of Zarih of Imam Hussian, is kept).   The interior of the building is in shades of green bordered with white. Once inside the hall area one is transformed into a magical land – with numerous exotic chandeliers which had been brought from Belgium (way back in the time of Nawab), mirrors (brought all the way from Europe) and crystal glass lamp stands. It’s because of these the imambada has also been called as Palace of Lights by various European writers. The Imambada also served as a mausoleum for the Nawab and his mother who are buried side by side inside the Azakhana.There are many antiquities which one can find inside the Azakhana; the royal throne of Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah, his crown (similarities with European crowns), a Parisian clock, a fish tank which had travelled all the way from Europe, Quran verses written in Islamic calligraphy in the shape of tiger, horse, bird etc. and many other such artefacts. Other than these one can find numerous Tazias (a representation of tombs of Imam Hussain and Hasan, grandsons of Prophet Mohammed, used in Moharram processions), made up of ivory, silver, sandalwood, wax etc. each a beautiful work of exquisite craftsmanship.One would find many people inside the Azakhana who would be willing to act as guides, they would say that they would require no fee for that, one may pay whatever one feels good. It’s entirely up to an individual to decide if one wants to go ahead with these self-styled guides or not. We refused and post our refusal were told that we couldn’t do photography inside the Azakhana (though there is no official notification for the same). On being questioned on this, they replied if you have any issues you can call up the office. We informed that we had taken photographs earlier also, they told that earlier it was allowed, now it is not. (Again there is no official intimation for the same).The Hussainabad Imambara or the Chota Imambada is under Hussianabad & Allied Trust (HAT). Unlike the Bada Imambada, where the restoration, repair etc. is under the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), HAT manages the affairs here. This is has resulted in improper restoration. There are numerous solar lights installed (by various individuals with ugly looking boards announcing their names), but the installations and the wires etc. are done in such a way that they have marred the beauty of the monument. This monument is worth a visit for many things; to understand the historical importance of an era where the East India Company was gaining its control over India, to understand the impact of European architecture & traditions over the royalty in Awadh/Oudh, to understand the impact of religion over period architecture, importance of proper restoration to save heritage etc. Few things to understand: please don’t expect this monument to be similar to the Mughal monuments, it’s neither comparable in architecture finery nor comparable in its grandeur. But one needs to admire the craftsmanship - the monument is built using locally available Lakhori bricks (Lakhori bricks were kiln baked, only 19 mm thick and normally about 10 cm x 15 cm. These bricks because of their small size were extensively used for creating finer details on the wall and column surfaces). Religious activities still happen in the complex – this complex plays an important role during the month of Moharram, so one needs to respect the religious sentiments.

Name: Gene R J
Title: A Shia Muslim congregation hall became a mausoleum complex.
Review: We visited here with combination site ticket ($7 for non-Indian), walking 1 km up Husainabad Rd from the more famous and older Bara Imambara. This Chhota congregation hall was built in 1838 and converted to a mausoleum when the ruling Nawab died in 1842. The tomb of his daughter was added to the side of the reflection pool on her death, then a treasury added to the other side for balance. This very beautiful complex, which includes a huge gateway entrance, is best viewed at the top of the steps of the main hall.  From this landing, 5 portals lead into the entry hall which proceed into the elaborate "Palace of Lights Hall".  Here chandeliers overlook the tomb, as well as 5 raised chapels, 2 featuring models of the Taj Mahal. This complex is in good condition being built 47 years after the Bara. From here we took an $3 Uber for 4 km southeast to The British Residency.

Name: lalani_13
Title: Awesome Place
Review: we went there as part of our tour and paid the entrance and saw many things. There were lots of people inside. We also took some photos.

Name: rsraghavan6
Title: Good
Review: this is a very good place one must visit this place it has its own beauty and Glory this place is related to the history of India and gives motivation to the Travellers and tell them about the culture and heritage of India we must be proud on this monument because nothing can come in between we and our patriotism I think the reason behind this monuments is to unite every Indian and see every religion in form of a United body named as India. every Indian must feel proud to have this monument on his land and he or she whatever religion follows, will not opened for the existence of this monument with these words I expect you to visit there and feel every word I have said thank you very much.

Name: 592abck
Title: Not very great
Review: You can skip this place if you have limited time. Go here only if you have ample time to spend in Lucknow.

Name: TravelbuggIndia
Title: Imambara
Review: Chhota Imambara is a beautiful structure. Visit this place when you are next in Lucknow to see great architecture beauty.

Name: Karl V
Title: Stunning
Review: A beautiful example of the Islamic influenced architecture in the city, the intricately decorated facade was enough on it's own, definitely a must see in Lucknow

Name: rajivdst
Title: Beautiful architecture
Review: Visit to Chhota Imambara and Bada Imambara is must in a trip to Lucknow. Architectural beauties. Both were built without using any steel or cement. This is still being used as a worship place.

Name: saurabh k
Title: REMAINS OF MUGHAL'S PERIOD
Review: To visit this place you have to buy combo ticket from bada imambara. It cost around 50* rupees and you can enjoy1)picture gallery ( situated behind clock tower) 2)chota imambara3)bhul bullaiya4)baradari.*for foreigners the cost may vary.

Name: nirmalsrivastava1000
Title: Imambara
Review: Being a local from lucknow ,I have visited Imambara like a 20 times date and the place gets me every time especially the terrace and the gallery . Seriously first timer should hire a guide ,if they don't want to get lost in her ,sometimes it gets seriously confusing.

Name: gauravkhattar
Title: Icon of Lucknow
Review: This place is an icon of Lucknow... a must see monument along with Bada Imambara and Bhul Bhulaiya...

Name: NouvelleTraveller
Title: Take a guide
Review: Beautiful - takes about one hour to cover everything. Many monuments in a single complex. Best to take a combined ticket. Take a guide for the labyrinth (bhool bhulaiya).

Name: Amit M
Title: Mogul Architecture
Review: Chhota Imambara is small than Bara Imambara but it is also unique to see the Mogul Architecture. Guide explained about the history of the Imambara and its importance. Devoted some half an hour there. Gardens are well maintained.

Name: amars777
Title: Also called Imambara Hussainabad Mubarak
Review: Built by Muhammed Ali Shah, the Nawab of Awadh in 1838.It was to serve as his own mausoleum and his mother. There is also a replica of Taj Mahal which houses Tomb of Princess Zinat AsiA, daughter of King Muhammed Ali Shah Bahadur, third king of Awadh

Name: BPB2012
Title: An old monument
Review: Chhota Imambara is not as big as Bara Imambara and hence named accordingly. It is a historical place attracting large number of visitors.

Name: randhirt2017
Title: Historical Place
Review: The chota imambara is kind of replica of bada imambara,when visit must take guide,there are an enrty fees and paid guides also available

Name: ShruthiRao09
Title: Lights will guide you!!
Review: Most of the people might miss out on this after seeing the Bada Imambara, but i say please dont. It is a true splendour to our eyes. The view is so diffent during the night from that during the night i.e once it turns dark. A must visit wonder if you are in Lucknow.

Name: Prashant Kumar
Title: Serene but small
Review: What's goodThe carvings on the wall are beautiful. Place is serene.What's not goodScale is small and takes not more than 10 minutes.What to doCompared to Bada Imambara, this is a carving on the wall. It's beautiful but small. Enjoy the serenity.

Name: Shivbalak
Title: Chhota imambara
Review: Imambara is topped by a golden dome, which when illuminated during festivities, offers a fantastic view. This complex is also known by the name of Husainabad Imambara.

Name: Jaspal_Singh
Title: Magnificent Place
Review: Regal place with very thoughtful, well designed architecture. Its advisable to have a guide, who can tell you subtle nuances of architecture. Well organized and repository of many appreciable artifacts. Grand and unique architecture is hallmark in Lucknow. Very much liked the water, pool, nouve design and quietness of place. Not to Miss!!

Name: asthecrowsfly2
Title: Lovely Monument
Review: We visited Chhota Imambara in February 2018.  This was a lovely monument, with beautiful gardens.  The grounds were quite peaceful, and our guide provided us with details about the various rooms and artifacts inside the monument.  We were not able to take photos inside the mosque, and I would recommend to wear a headscarf throughout your visit.  Definitely a destination worth visiting during your trip to Lucknow.

Name: mkeshav
Title: Holy mosque
Review: A nice place to visit once , luckily our tour guide was very good , he gave us ample time and described everything in detail and also described logics of many  architecture of building .

Name: masaccio
Title: Very pretty
Review: Whilst I enjoyed bara imambara more, this is a very pretty place with a lovely garden. Guards are sharp on photos at least as ou enter, though seemed not to actually care that much. The glass chandeliers are totally over-the- top, but then you’re in India!

Name: rashu23
Title: Great monument
Review: Chota Imambara is also one of the oldest monument of Lucknow, one should surely visit this place, you have to walk and capture the beautiful architecture in camera. you can hire guide also to know the history of this place.

Name: smitagupta
Title: the little Taj
Review: Interesting to see the wash area of the Nawab before he would go to the mosque.....our guide very enthusiastically explained how in "those days" they had a marbled tub where water came from the Gomti, and the unique system of heating the water, mixing the two, how a shower was made for the Nawab and a changing room was created in the small niche with curtains ......chandeliers from various countries that were gifted to the Nawab......not to miss

Name: Aakash A
Title: Good Architecture & History
Review: Good architecture. One will see a replica of Taj Mahal in this Chota Imaam bara. This is not so big as Bara Imaam. There is also Shahi Hamam where Nawab used to take bath. The place is designed in such a way that one used.

Name: Devaa
Title: Travelling in an era gone by!!!
Review: After walking down one of the broadest roadand passing through a sprawling gate  dotted with many historical structure from Bara Imambara i reached Chhota Imambara . Once again the dirt and filth on the entire stretch of road the least talk about is better. I just felt ashamed thinking the foreigners who come down here how they must be reacting. It was a small place compared to Bara Imamabara but beautiful architecture in white  and a nice location to click some photos.Had a quick tour .

Name: simham
Title: could see only hammam
Review: Tis is a memorial built in memory of chota imam. Since some religious activity was going on we did not go inside. But saw the Hamam (bathing house) of the nawaab.  It has internal supply of hot water, scented water which flows into another water tub, where the Nawab has his bath

Name: knightrider02
Title: Amazing architecture and history
Review: Nice architecture.One will see a replica of Taj Mahal in this Imaam bada.It is not as big as Bada Imam bada.There is also Shahi Hamam where nawab used to take bath. The place is designed in such a way that one used to get hot water at any time of the year in Shahi Hamam.Amazing architecture.

Name: Dalbir_S_Virdi
Title: Class Apart in comparison to Bada Imambada
Review: Not very far from Bada Imambada is located Chhota Imambada. Unlike Bada Imambada, here you need to deal with two sets of Guides. One who would tell you about history of Chhota Imambada and the "Shahi Hamam" (Royal Bath) inside the same campus and another set of attendants inside the Imambadas. For some reason, the first set of Guides are not allowed inside Chhota Imambada. You actually don't require a guide inside the Imambada because its comparatively a very small structure. Its beautifully decorated inside with Chandeliers from all over the European countries. There are few Graves inside and these belong to the Nawab's family members. The Shahi Hamam is quite an attractive place but poorly kept. Just an advise - start your journey from Bada Imambada and buy composite Tickets for all attractions that includes Chhota Imambada and Museum as well. Its only Rs. 50/- per person. An extra Rs. 5/- is charged for Still Cameras.

Name: Nikhil P
Title: mini imambara
Review: Located near to the Bada Imambad, this imbabada is small as the name suggests. It has its own charm and has been preserved beautifully. There are four graves over here belonging to royal family , the Mughal architecture reminds of its glorious past.

Name: drpriya86
Title: The chhota imambara
Review: Built in the memory of Hussain the younger grand son of Prophet Muhammad, this Imambara is very well decorated with chandeliers from all around the world. The Shahi hamam also shows the engineering of that era.

Name: naveen_oberoi
Title: Copy of Bara Imambara
Review: A replica of Bara Imambara, I personally find it average may be because I compared it Bara Imababara. However, it is a nice piece of work and is a also a worth visiting in lucknow.

Name: Sandeep V
Title: Nice place
Review: Chota Imambara, also known as Imambara Hussainabad Mubarak is an imposing monument located in the city of Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, India. Built as an imambara or a congregation hall for Shia Muslims, by Muhammad Ali Shah, the Nawab of Awadh in 1838,[1] it was to serve as his own mausoleumand his mother, who is buried beside him.[2]The significance of Panjetan, the holy five, is once again emphasized here with five main doorways. This Imambara consist of two halls and a Shehnasheen (a platform where the Zarih of Imam Husain is kept.) Zarih is the replica of that protective grill or structure which is kept on the grave of Imam Husain at Karbala, Iraq. The large green and white bordered hall of Azakhana is richly decorated with chandeliers and a good number of crystal glass lamp-stands. In fact, it was for this profuse decoration that the Imambara was referred by European visitors and writers as The Palace of Lights. The exterior is very beautifully decorated with Quranic verses in Islamic calligraphy .

Name: shriyans b
Title: masjid
Review: Chhota imambara is also known as Bhool bhulaiya. Which is located in Lucknow near hussainabad chauk. If you love to see tourist places. You can visit chhotta imambara. It is Beautiful place to see beautiful Monument, amazing architecture and the Crown of Nawab is also Displayed here for Public and Beautiful old Jhumar and Tajia can be seen in this monument Chhotta Imambara.A holy place inside, it contains all the beautiful designed tajia commemorating the sacrifice of Hussain in the war. I recommend you to visit this place at once.So I give total 5 star of this beautiful place.

Name: parusharouthud
Title: Chota Imambara is  near Bada Imambara in lucknow.
Review: Chota Imambara is near Bada Imambara.There are  four graves, of the son, daughter and son-in-law of the King Mohammed Ali Shah and one of the lady. The architecture can be appreciated and is a must to visit place by Moghul architectural lovers.The beauty of Chandeliers form different countries can also be seen.

Name: Zaheer C
Title: Mini Imambara
Review: Its a mini version of the humongous bada imambada.It has calm and serene environment that will give you a relaxed feeling

Name: Debojyoti S
Title: A must visit
Review: The grandeur of Mughal era is well reflected in the interiors of Chhota Imambara, located 2kms from the Bado Imambara.

Name: Daniel
Title: Beautiful place but very unorganised
Review: Beware, there is no fixed price for guides, they just ask you to give whatever you feel like giving. Of course, they are nice at the end also but they make you feel bad for what you give. There are two places that need guides or two places where you will be approached. Just talk to them that you will give them Rs. 30 for the first one and Rs. 30 for the second one.

Name: mukul78
Title: Nice Architecture
Review: Must visit. Excellent and beautiful Chandeliers form different countries with other places of interest. Take guide for knowing the complete history.

Name: sanjivsony
Title: For Click  nice place
Review: It was a nice place Front view is marvelous and for Photo it is good. Over all its good.Gardens are maintain properly.

Name: HOMPRS
Title: Architecturally sound
Review: Just 700 mrts from bada imambara is this comparatively smaller place where you get to see chota imambara and shahi hamam. Hire a guide if you are very much into history.Note: See chota imambara first and then bada imambara

Name: SRIKAKOLAPU
Title: see it along with bada imambara and bul bulaya
Review: The three places can be covered in a day and these are amazing architectures and engineering marvels at their best and the accoustic engineering is sure to leave you spell bound

Name: vipin k
Title: Similar to Bata imambara
Review: Another historical place to visit in Lucknow which depicts the Indian Muslim history and ancient culture..must visit  place

Name: Rohit RC
Title: Beautiful at sunset time
Review: Chhota Imambara was built by Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah (1837-42). It is more ornate in design with gilded dome, several turrets, exquisite chandeliers said to be brought from Belgium, gilt-edged mirrors and colourful stuccos which adorn the interiors.The tombs of Muhammad Ali Shah and other members of his family are inside the Imambara.There are some very interesting artefacts like a bottle that has a model of the Imambara. An ivory made model. Quran written on a small sheet of paper with rice edge. There’s a hammam at the entrance. There’s a description of the showers and hot water supply that’s interesting. There are guides available. At sunset you can get some beautiful pictures.

Name: Dhyan Chand
Title: Dedicated to light
Review: Chota Imambara was a congregation hall for Shia Muslims built by Muhammad Ali Shah, the third Nawab of Awadh in 1838 This structure serves as a mausoleum for four graves, of the son, daughter and son-in-law of the King Mohammed Ali Shah and one of the lady. This is the small scale copy of the TAJ MAHAL

Name: Aarav K
Title: Amazing Architecture
Review: I just keep going here. I find this place very great. It's Architecture is amazing. Must see location. Must visit.

Name: agarwalshubhangi
Title: Historic
Review: Chhota Imambara is equally famous as bada Imambara situated at Chowk in Lucknow. It is one of the most visit places for any tourist and gives a historic view and feel.

Name: TomSen1961
Title: The Nawabi Awadh
Review: Great place, with wonderful feeling. As you visit this place you get enthralled and find the Lucknawi heritage enchanting a nice place to be when in Lucknow.

Name: Alok Singh
Title: Nice Place
Review: What a place. It is small as compare to bada imambara  so less crowdy but well maintained. Nice place to visit if you are in lucknow

Name: Vinay Kariwala
Title: Lots of history
Review: Visited with a few friends. The place has a lot of history, which can be best learnt about by hiring a guide.

Name: Footprints727663
Title: Most Prominent Historical Structure
Review: I went to Chhota Imambara. Chhota Imambara is often touted as the most prominent historical structure of Lucknow by many locals. Architecturally, it is a wonderful amalgam of Charbagh, Indo-Islamic and Persian structural designs. It is great place to go.

Name: StephanieO34
Title: Little gem, but cluttered
Review: The Chhota Imambara (small meeting-hall of the Imam) is a little gem, with its tomb in the style of the Taj Mahal, with a plainly-decorated copy opposite for symmetry, surrounding an ornamental pool and garden, with an entrance gate on the fourth side. The Imambara is beautifully decorated with stone fretwork on the outside. Inside however we found it totally cluttered, the ceiling covered in lamps and chandeliers, and every niche and surface taken up with a strange assortment of objects, mostly gifts to the builder, Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah. An intriguing place for a brief visit.

Name: wilsongirl
Title: Another beautiful building
Review: Lucknow has lots of beautiful buildings and is worth a visit but only a short stay.  You can visit most of the attractions in a day.

Name: ashok_shrikhande
Title: Chota Imambara
Review: The Chhota Imambara, is one of the most beautiful and attractive buildings in the old Lucknow city. Chota Imambara, the 19th century building is also known as the palace of lights because of its decorations and chandeliers during special festivals. It is more ornate in design with gilded dome, several turrets, exquisite chandeliers said to be brought from Belgium, gilt-edged mirrors and colourful stuccos which adorn the interiors.

Name: neha763
Title: A perfect place for outing
Review: Beautiful place. Enough Said, filled with Spooky tales and the guides will only be happy to help you. With the beauty of the place is compounded by the interesting Technology used in bygone Era that keep you enthralled.

They have a superb collection of Chikan Kurtis of varied colours and design – both long (more) and short as well as for men and women (obviously more). It’s quite reasonably priced. The salesman was very courteous, knowledgeable, and not pushy at all. He showed us pieces as per our likings and demands. In fact we ended up visiting the same store twice as we forgot to buy a piece for someone. So we made another trip and met the same salesman on the next day. We bought three women’s Kurtis and one men’s Kurta. Would definitely recommend to anyone who would like to buy genuine stuff at a reasonable price without sacrificing their patience and comfort.

Review: Constantia House is actually a piece of French architecture, used as a college for Boys named La martniere Colledge, one of the best college of Uttar Pradesh, entrance is grand and its main hall below the main dome of the building is a piece of art, must add in your itineraries if planning to visit Lucknow.

Name: rajputprincess

Review: A must see on a trip to Lucknow.  Old elite College for Boys with a lot of history. The Constantia building is worth exploring.

Review: Great place to visit. The history behind the school is immense and extremely interesting, especially if you are British

Name: Siddhartha Biswas
Title: Magnificent
Review: Containing history in its premises, this is one breathtaking building. It houses a chapel, a library and a ornate foyer. The drawing room is preserved and speaks of a pure colonial time. Recommended to all those who love these bits of history.

Name: Aarav K
Title: Attractive House
Review: This is amazing place. Architecture is fantastic. I like this place very much. You all must visit once.

Name: Rajani B

Review: This building is also glorified during to its role in the Indian Freedom Struggle.  It houses a college and this college played a role during siege of Lucknow during 1857 Independence war.  The architecture is also remarkable.

Name: KhwajaSaif
Title: Labor et Constantia
Review: a must visit if you happen to be in north India , an excellent example of European architecture in India which is now one of the most esteemed Boys schools of India .

Name: RaviDeva16
Title: An Architectural Marvel
Review: A school that is in a grand palace! A summer retreat for a journeyman who made a name for himself away from home, then willed it to be transformed into an educational institution after his death.

Name: Pallavi S
Title: La Martiniere Building
Review: Many stories abound around this beautiful building. The most bizarre is that the statues on  top of the building come alive at night and dance. Many ghost stories also are attributed to this place. It is a very imposing edifice and one of the landmarks of Lucknow.

Name: AKHIL008
Title: now it has turned into world class educational insitute
Review: worth a visit can be seen once ...mainly its now turned into college so not many go there to see it...

Name: Malik61
Title: FASCINATING, A MUST SEE
Review: By far the best maintained historical building in Lucknow of the Nawab era now housing a great educational institution.

Name: MananDhuldhoya
Title: Takes one's breath away
Review: We couldn't go in because it had shut for the day but even from the outside, it is breathtaking. From its sweeping driveway to the lions and other beast carved into the facade, this building is a lustrous remnant of the Raj.Go before 4 p.m. to see the inside.

Name: GurgaonTrotwood
Title: Stunning
Review: This place at this time is a school, and therefore I went there with fairly low expectations, but how wrong I was. The campus and the building is packed with history and building itself is very beautiful. Must visit in Lucknow.

Name: YungJesse
Title: Mesmerizing Beauty
Review: Sadly I only got to see this place on my last day in Lucknow. Amazing European architecture that adds to the diversity of monuments in the city. Didn't hear about it as much from the locals, but after seeing it, I'd recommend coming here above some of the more talked about sites.The entire campus is meticulously maintained, making it a very comfortable atmosphere. I envy the students who spend their days on these grounds.

Name: VijayshreeGattani
Title: Labore et Constantia!
Review: Beautiful French architecture and rich taste of history. Simply mesmerising. Sad that General Claude Martin never had a chance to live in this grand residence. The place now runs a school and this building is a dormitory. Students here should be proud to be a part of such great heritage.

Name: Kajol P
Title: Constantia House: Awestruck at this beauty!
Review: Constantia House is a dreamy place with it's breathtaking architecture and beauty.  Definitely one of the best places in Lucknow! A must visit!

Name: iSaurabh S
Title: Not a very great place !!
Review: Lovers of old architecture shall appreciate the place. This is a monument converted into a school. Nothing great to see. Looking from far - it appears to be a "khandhar". Safety is also a concern.

Name: GypsyAna
Title: A piece of history not to be missed!
Review: The grand building of the Constantia House is probably one of the most majestic structures I've ever seen. The main building of the sprawling La Martinere College, Constantia House makes you "feel" history through its corridors and beautifual arch ways. I left only wishing I could have studied at an institution that housed so much history!

Name: PrernaJaiswal
Title: Glorious Glory!
Review: Glorious!! This place is beautiful and a must visit when in Lucknow. You are bound to feel jealous of the resident scholars who inhabit this building - yes ! It is a school - La Martiniere College for Boys, and this building houses the dormitory and resident complexes. If are in time and can arrange for a visit to the crown or the cellar where the tomb of the founder is, you should.. all the detective novels and Dan Browns you've ever read will come to life!

Name: wish2traveltheworld
Title: A Chapter from History
Review: This place is related to history and is a good example of british architecture. Visiting here you can learn about the history of the place and major general claude of british army. A must visit if you can.

Name: Roshni S
Title: An architectural feat
Review: Designed by the famous French architect Claude Martin, who founded schools in Lucknow and Kolkata, the Constantia House is shaped like a giant wedding cake. The heritage building has a running college and beautiful lawns all around. It is in one of the most beautiful locations of Lucknow.

Name: Yash G
Title: Epic place related to revolt of 1857 and the siege of Lucknow.
Review: A historical palace cum school, built between 1790 and 1800. Best school in Lucknow and one of the best in the world.

Name: foodieebyheart
Title: Must Visit!
Review: This structure is an example of great architecture, the plus point is the beauty & how well maintained it is now. Full campus has its own history & facts attached.

Title: Never miss it
Review: One of the famous place to witness, you will highly appreciate the  British architecture , see it both at the daytime and in the evening time, if permitted go upto 2nd floor and see the Library , how beautifully and systemically everything has been maintained, see the building from inside and you  will love it.

Name: SUROJIT G
Title: Grand structure
Review: Do take prior permission from the school authorities to visit get a chance to see the Constantia House and also do have a glimpse for the memorial of the founder of the school  Major General Claude La Martiniere

Name: fussy
Title: I guess this is the school?
Review: Very beautiful. But if this is la martiniere then can only see from outside as working school, but nice to see the outskirts of Lucknow

Name: mishrarohit9
Title: Constantia House Worth visting
Review: Building is quite outstanding, location as it is situated on the banks of river gomti , Must See attraction in Lucknow

Name: Rajeshwar Dayal Mathur
Title: Another must visit place in Lucknow
Review: Major-General Claude Martin, a French soldier in the British Army built his haveli on the banks of Gomti in 1794, in memory of his love - Constance and named it Constantia.It has been built in a mix of Indo-European design with a touch of Mughal architecture.He willed that Constantia along with two other buildings of his were to be given to the foundation of schools. La Martiniere - Calcutta, La Martiniere - Lyons and La Martiniere - Lucknow. He also wished that his mortal remains should be laid to rest in the basement of this building. He died on 13Sept1800 and his remains were buried in the basement.The building was converted into a school 1840, forty years after his death. Today Constantia is one of the most respected and reputed educational institutions of India.Since the school is on banks of Gomti, on the steps leading to the main building flood levels marked on the wall. Now a wall has been raised to prevent flooding.

Name: Susej B
Title: A historic School !
Review: 1. This is the main part of the building, 'The Constantia'. It was never known as Constantia House. Having spent 12 years in this place 'My School', I can state this with authority.2. This was  built as the residency of Major General Claude Martin at Lucknow between 1776 - 1800. At present a School since it was founded in Sep 1845. 3. There already exists a review on trip advisor at, 'Attraction_Review-g297684-d2445127-Reviews-La_Martiniere_College-Lucknow_Uttar_Pradesh'. 4. May I request the 'admin' at Trip Advisor to combine the two.5. The central part of the building has been named Constantia some photographs are uploaded, however these photographs have not been shot by me. The Old Students have contributed.

Name: Deba_Nandy
Title: Must visit, situated insdte La Martiniere school Campus
Review: Around 5 mins walk fromthe main entrance of La Martiniere school campus main gate, it is a grand architecture to click pictures of. A must visit if you are on a sightseeing trip to Lucknow.

Name: shridhar g
Title: Republic de frenchaise
Review: It is very FRENCH in its design made by the French general.it is big and a must see as French architecture in this part is very uncommon.Nearby is river gomti who makes it more picturesque.It is not well maintained like all the historic monuments of Lucknow and has witnessed some BOLLYWOOD SHOOTINGS.

Name: ar_faraz
Title: French Architectural Masterpiece
Review: the design of building is quite outstanding, location as it is situated on the banks of river gomti.

Name: YashwantDShah
Title: Best French Architecture in India
Review: La Martiniere Boys' College also mentioned as 'Constantia' is one of the best French architecture in India made by the famous French General Claude Martin.Many films like 'Gadar' and 'Always Kabhi Kabhi' were shot here. It is also the only school in the world to have won battle honors.

Name: dsdurgesh28
Title: good
Review: this was a very ancient building. Excellent carving. But due to time it is fading away so i request local government try to save this precious geam.

Name: Dwarak Naidu
Title: Excellent for walking/jogging or cycling
Review: The track and park are by the riverfront, neat/clean and adequately maintained. Did not spot any squatters, security is adequate.

Name: Rohit B
Title: Excellent location!
Review: There couldn't be any better place than this one for a morning or an evening walk. Very peaceful and calm, and on the banks of the Gomti river, this Riverfront is very well made with good walking tracks and even a small amphitheatre. A good place to spend a nice relaxing moment here whenever in Lucknow.

Name: Rahul Sharma
Title: Gomti Riverfront Lucknow Kids Play Zone
Review: Gomti Riverfront Lucknow Kids Play Zone is one of the most happening places in Lucknow throughout the day. It is a place where kids love to play for hours.  Gomti Riverfront Lucknow Kids Play Zone was developed by the Irrigation department Sharda Canal division Lucknow. The structures look artistic are world-class play equipment are Play is a critical component of child development. Besides being a foundation for learning, it is also vital for emotional, social, physical, and intellectual development.  In fact, kids who don’t get plenty of tending to develop a wide range of problems into adulthood.Play and growth are intertwined. Play is one of seven emotional systems of the human brain and on par with other human emotional instincts such as happiness, fear or love.Children’s physical, social-emotional, cognitive, and creative development is not only supported by play, it is developed through playThe World Health Organization recommends that all children and adolescents should participate in moderate to vigorous physical activity for a least 60 minutes a day.
